Review Text: this Hindu temple belongs to lord Shiva,this temple in the middle of the ocean  There are small shops on the road

Unfortunately, due to COVID, the Fort overall was very empty and most of the temple was closed to us. Otherwise, this was a very lovely temple to visit. The statues were amazing to look at as well as the architecture of the temple itself.

The temple is quite a sacred one that is worshiped by locals belonging to different religions. It is quite colorful and well-kept. The ‘lovers leap’ is a steep rock that looks over the deep ocean. Do not forget to recite your wishes into the ear of “Nandi” statue and watch the serene beauty of the Trinco bay over a drink of an iced Lemon juice on the way to the temple.

it was nice to visit a hindu temple, yet if there has some English descriptions, it should be nicer! got a bonus checkpoint before leaving which was a budda parade. p.s. shoes off and about 100m walk, beware of the wet ground

Right on the Indian Ocean, this temple is a relatively new version of an ancient temple that Portuguese invaders destroyed several centuries ago. But Hindu Tamil priests keep the services going, several times a day. This temple was out of bounds for several years during the civil war and is now opening up again as peace returns to Sri Lanka

If in the area, you must come and see this holy temple. it is ornate and pretty. It does get hot, and although there is some carpeting your feet will still get hot. There are plenty of stalls on the walk up, and you are also passing through the old portuguese fort, now home to the SL army. Odd to think that only 9 years ago this area was part of the civil war, but now so peaceful.

The view is breath taking from the top of the cliff. If you go in the early morning you can enjoy the sun rise from here. As well participate for a traditional Hindu prayer and learn a little bit of the Hindu culture and history.

This ancient Hindu Temple dedicated to Shiva has indie interesting murals of Ravana, the Shiva devotee. We were present for the evening Aarti and it was very nice to see the devotion and faith of the people. Ravana's cut - in the rocks outside the temple has an interesting story
Hindu temple inside old fortress. Interesting to walk around but an uphill climb from the Fish Market area so maybe best to take a tuc tuc there and back.
i love every inch of this place... the view was just breath taking, and the temple architecture was absolutely gorgeous
In this temple u can feel a holy energy and full respect for Hindu religion. Please cover your shoulders and take off your shoes

The location of this temple complex is amazing. Right next to the ocean, Since it is on top of an hill, the views from the complex are breath taking. The temple is very religious and is in indian style.

After seeing a few Buddhist temples this was our first Hindu temple. The drawings and statues inside the temple are beautiful and impressive. Unfortunately you’re not allowed to take any pictures inside the temple.

One of the most ancient temples of South Asia ,dedicated to Lord Shiva, dates back to the period of Rama mythologically,  and to the 6th Century B by historians. Said to have been worshiped by Ravana , ithe temple had one of the Suyambu Lingams as the main deity. During the 17th Century AD ( around 1630 s) the temple was supposed to have been razed to the ground by foreign invaders to build a harbour. The local priests hurriedly burred the important idols of the Gods before leaving the temple , fearing vandalism. And in 1956, in an underwater exploration , the old temple ruins were found, Besides a lot of inscriptions about the temple etc were also discovered . All the bits and pieces dicovered were put together and now a grand temple is there once again for us to worship. A great work of reconstruction of the temple as well as the history. The temple is sung about gloriously by the great poet saints. Sambandhar and Arunagirinathar. the Pandya Chola and Chera kings of south India  were said to have patronized and visited the temple.The Vilva tree is the Sacred tree of this temple. In 2013, when the civil works were undertaken for the temple, a beautiful Nandhi idol was discovered and it was found to belong to 11th Centurt AD. People believe that there many be many more to be excavated. The temple is also a seat of Sakthi Peetam, where the feet of the Amman were supposed to have been assocoated.

Had no idea what to expect but was surprised ,very interesting Hindu temple. Leave your shoes with the shoe man for 20rp wash your feet with the plastic cup and walk up the hot stairs to the entrance. Perched on a clifftop with great views out over the ocean. Apparently it's a green zone no plastic or rubbish allowed in but look over the fence and there it all is !! Why throw it over the fence at a sacred places I don't understand It's a beautiful place and it's treated like a tip. The temple itself is outstanding ,the artwork over the top and incredibly colorful. Definitely worth a visit
We really enjoyed walk around this site. Well worth a visit. Vendors selling drinks and snacks close by. Great views of the bay
It's the most popular temple in Sri Lanka is Temple very beautiful in Sri Lanka you can find only two temples like this this Temple as a big history
Go for the views and look at the colonial buildings and grounds of the fort. Don't forget to have shoulders and knees covered. The ground from where you leave your shoes to the temple was scalding.
The temple of lord Shiva & has proven to be a temple that gent wishes and miracles. Please see image for the prayer time tables. Thanks

Beautiful colourful temple situated on a cliff inside Fort Frederick. Unfortunately we couldn’t get inside because we arrived at sunset and there was a ceremony going on. Nevertheless we treated ourself with some drinks and some spectacular views.
Located on a perfect sight with breathtaking scenic sea view, ideal time to visit early morning or evening!
Visiting this beautiful temple late in the afternoon, we found ourselves almost intruding on everyday Hindu live. But we met only smiles from the people :) Impressive and worth a visite!
We visited on weekend with family friends. A great experience to recommend others. Nice view over Trincomalee city.
King Ravana and his mother had worshipped God Shiva this place. Today a major place for Hindu pilgrimage located @ eastern coast. Full view of Indian oean
As you enter this place you can see loud music which can be for some people disturbing, but for me it was quite a fun. The place is very nice and offers a stunning ocean view.
We had a brief visit here, the temple is simple, has a very nice location and an interesting history, both in terms of recorded colonial history as well as legends
Beautiful place to visit and look at the grand colours used and kept so beautifully These are stunning places of worship
The temple excursion itself was an average experience. The surrounding views though offered some lovely photo opportunities.

This is an impressive temple worth visiting. The inside was beautiful and there were several areas around it to explore as well. Stunning views of the ocean from the path around the rocks. There are many people selling shells, children's plastic toys and sweets along the walk to the temple. You will have to leave your shoes and walk barefoot for a bit. Consider wearing socks if the sun has been heating up the ground.

This place is more than a temple. Build on the kliff it offers several amazing views and hidden spots along the steps curling down the hill. The Kovil itself is really worth seeing - in mornings around 7-8 am there is a service where you can participate and see prayers. Not many tourists luckily but local people are very inclusive and welcoming... No photos alowed inside - what a pitty as there are some lovely coulourful 3D fresques. Definitedly worth a visit.

Avoid going between 1 & 4 when there is no darshan. The view of the ocean is amazing from the staircase that goes down right across the main door of the temple. Best view of the ocean I have had in a decade.

I went there with lot of expectations after reading the reviews, especially of the views from the top, since this temple is located up a small hill. Tuk Tuk will charge your 150 LKR from the bus stand. Fredrick. I reached there only by 6 p.m. Hence did not look at the fort and went up the hill to the temple. You will have to walk the last 50 yards to the temple. There is a place where you can leave your footwear. The views of the sea and other places is good but you do not get a direct unhindered view. There is no view point as such. You will have to see through fences or over the walls or through the trees. Neither do you have a place to sit  so that you can sit and enjoy the views. The temple is one of the five ishwaram temple in Sri Lanka for Lord Shiva. The temple complex is small. You can spend maximum 30 minutes here.

This is such a wonderful temple. We went there during the pooja time and it was extremely good. Ravana's sward cut is a must see, it cannot be described. On the way to the temple you will find many deer.

A nice place to visit especially during the afternoon puja. The temple complex has some interesting sights apart from the main temple. The locals are very friendly and welcoming and they might even invite you to join them in a simple meal after the puja. As with almost all kovils in Sri Lanka, pictures are not allowed inside the main temple but men do not have to take their shirts off. The puja itself is more subdued compared to the ones we have observed in other parts of Sri Lanka.

prays time 6 am 8 am 11 am 4 pm , we can participating 11 am prayer, fruit baskets & coconuts can be purchased IN front of the temple, after the prayers they offering green gram milk rice ( Pongal rice )  & fruit salad. shorts are prohibited to enter the temple. we have to wear long sarong , skirts or leggings or trousers, children's can easily learn the history of the temple through the wall paintings & descriptions.
what a celebration of colors, smells, sounds and more....located on a very nice spot, overlooking the trincomalee bay and has a vey nice market. Recommended

This temple has a great location and contains some of the original artifacts that were once buried to hide them while the temple was destroyed.  It's interesting for its history, but its not the most stunning/elaborate of Hindu temples.  The large golden statue was hidden behind scaffolding when we visited.  The road up to the temple is lined with vendor stalls selling tourist wares.

This location is at the tip of the land at a high point and as such offers great views. It has a rich Hindu legend and so my parents were keen to visit it. You need to reach the naval base and from there, the only way up is a tuk-tuk (auto-rickshaw in Indian). Very elaborate art on the walls depicting a lot of history. We also bought some local sweet-meats on our way back and they were delicious!

A must thing to in Trinco & amazing view always make me visit. The whole area surrounded by water & green, the temple history portrait nicely on the walls. Highly recommend for nature lover & first time visitors.
Best view of Trincomalee and the Temple is very impressive Colorfull with a lots of paintings, statues and sculptures: we loved this place!

The Koneswaram temple is one of the main highlights of the east coast of Sri Lanka in Trincomalee. The temple is located high above the bay, and you can view the breathtaking and awe-inspiring scenery on all sides. The site is a religious pilgrimage for the Hindus and is also known as the Kailasa of the South. The Koneswaram temple is one of the five “Pancha Ishwarams” (abodes of Shiva) which has been built to worship Lord Shiva- the supreme God of Hinduism.

This is a Historical attraction being located in the Fort Fedrick built by Pirtugese and built on the destroyed Gokanna Budhist Temple in 1620.  It is devoted to daisy Koneshwaran. A huge statue of him is built outside the temple. The temple and the statue are colourful. In any faith,  can visit inside but have to remove shoes and have to wear a modest dress covering the knees. Many devotees are seen worshiping and praying. This is famous for ladies to expect babies and they hang a small model of a cot for the purpose to get fulfilled. The view over sea is amazing. King Rawana' s cut from his sword which is also called as "Lover's Leap" is also nearby. During the day the sand is not  and I recommend you to wear shocks. With socks you can enter the temple also. There  are ladies found nearby that tell your future by seeing the hands.
This was my dream from around 4 to 5 years to visit the holy place. I am truely grateful to the lord for giving me the opportunity. Best kovil I have seen eith so much history
The temple on the shore next above the sea level and one of the most prominent places in Srilanka.It is well maintained and very clean.The view from the temple also isvery good.
Beautiful Hindu temple dedicated to the gods of fertility. Beautiful views of the city and the ocean. You can see floating turtles in the sea and whales by telescope when you're lucky.

Seeing the temple was an interesting experience. Please remember that if there are people who are not able to walk a long distance, they can go in a vehicle all the way up to the temple. There is a sign that says no vehicles are allowed but there are exceptions.
Really blessed to be here is an amazing architecture,culture,the view is spectacular it’s a Hindu temple dates way back from 16th century if you come to Trincomalee is must visit destination.

Excellent  beautiful place to visit. Its a place of worship for Hindus but people from all religions go there to get blessings. There's a belief that you will be blessed with child if you got blessings for this temple. Also you can get a beautiful view of Trincomalee sea from a very high level. You have huge rocks forming this location and one of the points is called loves leap. There's so many stories attached to this place I think you can google this stories. A must place to visit in Trincomalee.

We’ve visited a TON of temple in our months travelling India and Srilanka and I have to say this is one of the most beautiful! It’s perched on the edge of a cliff (lovers leap) and the paint work inside and outside is second to none. Leading up the the temple there are lots of stalls selling bits and bobs (the sweet stalls are great). If you’re thinking I’ve seen enough, make this your last you won’t regret it

You can walk to this place from Trinco town...try it... the view from the top is beautiful.... you can see beautiful seas from here... on the way to the top where you find the Statues u find many street shops where u good buy collectibles.souvenirs, food items etc. Have a visit if u travel to Trinco!

No regret as all friends told to visit. Was there at 4pm and lucky as evening prayers started. Managed to join and have good view and blessing. Top view was good especially the ocean and the rocks. Picture scenic view from Top and deers freely every where.

One of the must see if you are travelling on the eastern coast.  This is indeed a strategic place where you can have control over eastern part of Indian Ocean as nothing in between till Andaman Sea. The view of Lovers' Leap or Ravana's Cleft is beautiful. Also walking all over naked feet is another experience. Listening the Temple Bell at the time of sunset along with traditional music coming from inside was unique.
I had seen a lot of Buddha buildings, so this was the first time I saw something of the Hindu religion! Very nice and beautiful, if you are in Trincomolee, please visit this place!
Don't ever miss this amazing temple. If you need a closer darshan inside the temple, you need to wear dhoti or saree. Else you can see from outer Praharam. Dont miss the beautiful sunset..

The Tirukoneswaran Hindu temple is situated in such a beautiful area that it is so serene to look around and feel blessed. The temple itself is very rich in history as this is the place where Lord Rama is supposed to have installed the second lingam after he defeated King Ravana of Lanka, on Lord Shiva's instructions. Beautiful Temple. A lot of vibrations. Many other sites in the temple area to see such as the Ravana statue and the Ravana cut, which has its own story.
Early morning is the best time to visit, less crowd and heat will be less.Pooja starts 6:30am, early morning. You could drive all the up to the kovil(if you are driving a car or a van).
This temple is one of the two Shiva temple in the Island which got revered by Devaram poets from Tamil Nadu. Other temple is Ketheeswaram temple.

Visited on an early morning excursion with the family. Love the rich colours of this temple and with few people around you got a definite sense of peace and calm which was appreciated. Lots of little nooks and crannies with different deities and enjoyed the views of the Indian Ocean as well. Would definitely recommend any travellers to Trinco to tick this exquisite temple off the list.

very colorful temple, no pictures are allowed inside, very decent drawings with a lot of colors. as you walk to it you can see a lot of antelopes, very nice scenery of the sea and good souvenir shops (you must bargain to get a good price)
This is an old Hindu temple here. The view from here is amazing. This is in the Fort Frederick army  camp.

Koneswaram temple is very old and one of the most important Hindu temples in srilanka.. Very nice place with so much Divinity.. Lord shiva shower his unconditional love and blessings from this kovil. Temple has a long history of thousands of years and lot of miracles have taken place. The view from the temple is unbelievable and can see the beauty of trincomalee. A must place to visit
Very beautiful place in Sri lanka.nice view. Important place in Hindu culture.we all worship this historical place....
Holy place to visit. Beautiful temple with a amazing view of the coastline. Lady selling juice was very friendly with natural juice with nice sitting arrangment overlying the beach

The temple complex has lots of points of interest as well as being in a spectacular position. Lots of history to absorb and to see the worshippers performing various acts of belief was fascinating. Well worth a visit and allow at least half an hour or more.

Nice walk up the hill with fantastic nature and animal life, from the top you get a nice view of the ocean and city. The temple is beatiful, we enjoyed the view and freshly pressed juice before heading down again.
Really not to be missed! Very impressive, we arrived at 8 am during prayer. I recommend anyone a visit!

Busy Hindu temple complex. You are not allowed to take pictures inside the temple. There are plenty of interesting statues and pictures of the Hindu Gods. Very colorful and alive. There are tame deer and peacocks in the area.

A nice trip out, what a setting..set in a military fort you get to see a different side.  The temple is amazing, bare in mind the temperature of the floor as you do have to remove your shoes.... But lovely.

Our tuktuk driver wanted to show us this place, because he wanted to visit the temple himself. It was really interesting to go with someone who was familiar with and reverent to each part of the temple and surrounds. There is a not to be missed main worship hall that has a awesome ceiling, full of figures, and don't miss the view from the front of rock, with the shines in the rock wall nooks. Everyone was was very happy and friendly. The fact that Buddhist monks were among the mix of demographics visiting a Hindu temple made our visit more rich and interesting. The deer were a bonus.

Sitting on the cliff... when u enter you are greeted by a huge statue of Lord Shiva and this leaves you in awe. Within the temple also is the Shakti Peedam as it is the same area, just have to read the signs. We were fortunate to be in time for Darshan, was a great feeling!

If you visit the Koneswaram temple you will see many of the most famous places in Sri Lanka. You have to go through the Fort Frederick which was built by Portugese during the time they invaded Sri Lanka on your way to the temple. This tour through take you back through the ages to the colonial times. One past the Fort buildings you have to walk up to the temple. It is Advisable to go there before 10,00 AM or after around 4.00 PM because the ground could be really hot and you have to walk bare foot. There are many impressive statues of Hindu gods in the temple. Within the temple premises is the famous 'lovers leap' a picturesque sight. On your way back visit the War Museum where you could see parts of ships built in 18 hundred as well as the weapons captured from the guerilla outfits LTTE and JVP. It is also an educational tour. If you go on a Sunday stroll down the Trincomalee city. I stayed at Sober Island Resort which is a good place to stay. Its a resort inside a sort of a jungle but you have to be recommended by a person in the SL Navy to book the resort.

One of my favourite Hindu Kovils in Sri Lanka. Way to Thirukonrshvaram through Fort itself is full of amazing sceneries including dears both sides of the road. The small market just before the Kovil is also really colorful and last June I bought so many stuff from there. With my mediocre Tamil Proficiency I managed to learn a lot about Tamil kings and the history behind this Kovil. The view of the sea from the Kovil is simply magical.
It´s a nice and peaceful place with a very good view. We walked up to the hill... would do it again...
Come in the evening around 6 or 7 PM to see the amazing sunset from the top of the hill and the ceremony in the temple. One of the most beautiful temples we visited in Sri Lanka.

Located inside the old fort and restoration is amazing. Try go when they are doing the 'Pooja' it is a soul touching experience. Recommended to walk from fort door as the walk is quite nice ( if you like walking ). View from the Kovil is breathtaking. Words cant say how beautiful it is.

Great views from the top and a bunch of deer and peacocks were roaming about freely.  It's of great religious importance to Hindu folk as well. Located within an army camp and a lot of history to be discovered here.

Most of the Hindu people visit this place, and its nice to see this Kovil. Young married ladies come here to wish for a baby with a huge faith. There are drawings inside the Kovil and it says many stories related to Hindu culture.

It is a grand Temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. There are other shrines housing Ganesha, Murugan, Bhadrakali, Parvathi etc. On the entrance side sits Lord Shiva in the form of a big golden coloured statue. The Temple itself is perched atop the Konesar malai a hillock. The Temple is well maintained with poojas and other rituals. It is also known as  thousand pillared Temple.

A huge temple god awaits you at the entrance. The souvenir shops up to the entrance with their plastic spoil the picture considerably. There are only a few traditional stalls in between - a shame. The temple is very colorful, but pleasant and worth a visit, especially for the great view over the bay.
historic temple, but avoid going midday as one has to remove footwear & the road/ground gets far too hot -likely to end up with blisters

This is an important Hindu temple and primarily a religious place. The sea views around the temple are stunning and lovers leap is beautiful although the sight has many sad endings!! The spotted deer that roam around are also worth a look. We enjoyed spending about 45-60 mins here but you could spend a lot longer. Well worth a visit if you are in the area.

About 15min drive from Trinco Blu, this is on Fort Fredrick. An old temple , it is worth a visit. Super hot by the day, it is hard to walk barefoot. Main diety is Shiva. Didn't witness any special puja when we were there. Lovely ocean views from the top. Lot of over priced shops on the way to the temple.

It was a beautiful temple located on top on the hill overlooking the indian ocean. We bought pooja tray from one of the stalls for reasonable price to experience the rituals and must say it was simple and tourist friendly. The priest was helpful and friendly, The pooja started on time and it was simple and short pooja. Thank you temple management for giving us this beautiful experience.

We are told there are over 1800 steps but they are shallow and should not prove a problem for anyone of average fitness.  More of a challenge is getting to the final high spot over steep, smooth rock with a few footholds, there is a hand rail but you may have to let go to let people down!  You will need a head for heights at the top the barriers are low but the view is stupendous.  There are several other shrines on the way up with their own story and well worth the visit.  For more information visit the web page for the temple.
This is a very special site which you should not miss in Trincomalee. One of the 5 most important religious sites in Sri Lanka. Amazing views and nice deer on the way back.
Worth a visit because of the views. The temple is a temple. A lot of commercial stands before you enter.

In terms of location,this temple is no1. Located at the top of a rockhill overlooking the Indian Ocean,i think no other temple can match its beauty. Its a very colourful temple with so much history and a lot of detailing. My only regret is was unable to see the giant koneswaram statue as it was under construction. Lots of deers and peacocks enroute the temple. The entrance is via the Fort Frederick...you feel like going back in time. I spent about 2 hours here.
Rich in history, mystery and great people. The small walk towards Koneswaram is very interesting with handmade crafts and little toys for kids.
Absolutely worth visiting when in trinco. Would recommend packing socks and wearing them when visiting as the ground gets almost unbearably hot in basement. Cash is required to pay for storing shoes.
Visit this temple when a mass is going on! It´s an expierience you will not forget! Really a Must-See in Sri Lanka!

The biggest tourist attraction is Koneswaram Temple, on a high clifftop overlooking the ocean. A temple was first established here around 500 BC, but when the Portugese took over around 1620, they demolished the temple and used stones from the rubble to build a fort at the base of the cliff. The fort remains and is now a military base, but the temple has been rebuilt and the site's antiquity attracts many pilgrims.
Nice trip in 'trinc', views are superb, temple is beautiful Hindu piece of work, certainly worth the detour (entrance is free)
On the top of the rock through the dutch fort. You can see the far waters of east beach from the top. Nice location

We went there during late January and unfortunately it turned out to be a very hot day. You have to leave your transport a fair way from the temple and walk the rest of the distance bare foot. We found it very uncomfortable to walk on the tarmac which was  extremely hot for us. Managed to get as close as you can to get a good view of the temple  but could not venture in.

I loved going to the temples because it helped broaden my perspective on different cultures and religions as well as my own. You have to go barefoot for a large portion of this temple which was fine for me and my wife but not everyone will be comfortable with it.

A must see temple in Trincomalee with such a beautiful view. This temple holds a lot of history and is situated right by the water and looks out to the mountain. There are many street vendors and a cafe along the way if you want to grab a quick bite and buy souvenirs.

Temple is located on top of a hill. Easy access & easy parking. A lot of small shops have been allowed between the car park & the temple which gives a bit of a commercial touch. View from top of the hill is fantastic. Lovers leap is situated adjoining the temple. Temple itself is very well maintained & worth a visit.
To see, Hindu temple on the rocks after Fort Frederic. Saroung and long sleeve required to access the site Free

The sacred temple is abode of Lord Shiva & is also a Shaktipeeth. There is also belief that Ravana mediatated & worshipped Lord Shiva at this place. There is also a Ravana cut rock. Truly amazing place to visit.
At the top of a hill and with very beautiful views we found this temple, full of color, we couldn't go inside, but you take a walk around the perimeter... very curious...
This was the temple that caught my eye and I wanted to go to Sri Lanka, Which I did in December 2018. Most amazing experience, beautiful temple and views of the sea was breath-taking

A very colourful Hindu temple set high on the cliff above the sea. Very important Temple for Hindus. Am not a massive fan of temple visits. This ticked a box and would probably tick many for temple aficionados.

This is one of my favourite temples I’m not Hindu but I alway feel drawn to this place. I’ve been 3 times now each time we visit Trincomalee. It’s beautiful, peaceful and full of history. I always wonder and marvel at how much energy, love, patience and hard work  goes into building these Hindu temples in Sri Lanka. Especially the hand painted shrines that surround the god statues. This Temple is built up high on the cliffs and we were told that young lovers that weren’t allowed to marry would come here and jump off the cliffs so they would be together forever. It’s know as Lovers Leap. The local people are also very friendly and welcoming but just be warned about the few people mainly ladies that will try and con you outside the temple at the end of the road. They insist on reading your palm for a price then tell you that you’re are cursed or put a curse on you and tell you it wil cost you more (a lot more) to remove it! Just downright cheeky! If you are visiting Tricomalee then this temple is a must.

This is another must see place with religious and historic value. It also has a great surrounding of the gorgeous sea. People be dressed modestly . Must wear cloth below the knee. Avoid visiting during the afternoon because has direct sun light .suitable for morning or evening

Visiting the Siva Ishwarams (Pancha Ishwarams) in Sri Lanka. The reunion with relatives in Jaffna took us to four of the Siva Temples in Sri Lanka during the first seven days of our Sri Lanka Odyssey. Our first stop, on March 3rd, was at the Munneswaram temple situated in a village in the Puttalam District. Hindus believe that it is one of the the five temples they need to visit in their life time. The others being Naguleswaram temple which we visited in Keerimalai in the Kankesanthurai district on March 4th and Thiruketheeshwaram in Mannar District and the Koneswaram temple in Trincomalee (Thirukonamalai) -- both the next day. All these, including Rameswaram in India form the five ancient temples (Ishwarams) dedicated to Shiva. According to Hindus, the Munneswaram temple near Puttalam is the temple where King Rama prayed to Shiva after killing Ravana to seek forgiveness over the death of many in the war. Hindus believe that the Naguleswaram temple's adjacent water tank, the Keerimalai Springs, has curative properties. The temple was largely destroyed by Jesuit missionaries following the Portuguese conquest of the Jaffna kingdom, restored by Arumuga Navallar in 1894. The Thiruketheeshwaram temple had existed for more than 2,400 years. During our visit to this temple, we witnessed a temple devotee from Vavunia singing Thevarams. His aim was to complete the 800 thurmurai thevarams in one month. The Trincomelee Koneswaram temple was built by the Cholas/Pandian kings. The temple is situated atop Konesar Malai, at a commanding position overlooking the Indian Ocean. It is also known as the "Mount Kailash of the South". The temple, mentioned in Mahabaratha and Ramayana, was visited by Arunagirinathar and is the easternmost shrine of the five ancient Ishwarams of Shiva on the island.

The Temple is situated on top of a hill, not far from the entrance to Trincomalee Harbour. The statue is spectacular and the interior of the Temple looks interesting. There are shops at the entrance to the Temple.

We reached the temple in the morning and had a good darshan. This temple is close to the shore. You will be able to see the sea from the top of the temple. The temple follows rituals as in Tamil Nadu. Once you enter the temple, you have the presiding deity of  lord shiva. You can easily spend 30 to 45 minutes in this temple. This is MUST visit temple in Sri Lanka.

You enter the temple after a nice walk down a winding road. As you turn into temple you see a HUGE statue of Lord Shiva - in bright blue ! The temple is not very big (unlike its counterparts in India), but airy and roomy. And  not very crowded like most temples in Sri Lanka... As you walk around the temple, its 2000+ year history begins to get into you ! The Bay looking stunning on the eastern periphery of the temple. Caution - the walk from the place you remove the footwear to the covered portion of the temple can be cruel on sensitive feet ! We reached at noon - and we really felt the heat. So plan your visit before 10 am or after 4 pm, if possible.

We visited this famous Koneswaran Temple situated on Swamy Rock within Fort Fredrick on 5th May 2018.  The vehicle park is about 150 metres from the temple itself.  After that we walked along the path leading to the temple.  All along the path are little shops selling various curios, flower and other offerings.  On the way up we saw some deer who seemed to be quite used to the crowds.  It is a safe haven for the here as they are quite safe and are protected. At the end of the path beyond a few steps is the statue of God Siva seated in lotus position, with its vehicle, the bull name Nandi.  This is a grand structure and stands out majestically as you approach the temple.  We came to the entrance to the main temple after passing this Siva statue.  Though we went inside to look at the grand sculptures and paintings, photographs were forbidden. A little beyond the temple entrance the view outside into the sea is beautiful, with many fishing boats.  The sheer drop at one of these places is called the “lover’s leap” where a distraught lady flung herself to the watery grave after watching her lover, a member of the Dutch foreign service, sailing away back to Holland. What struck me most were the little colourful baskets, said to be small versions of baby cots, hanging on one of the trees towards the sea side under flags of various colours.  These are offerings from childless couples asking for divine intervention for them to have their baby. We spent a thoroughly enjoyable morning visiting this beautiful and historic location.
Koneswaram Temple is an  Interesting Place to visit and study. A history of decades and we had a wonderful time.

Very crowded, interesting place. You dont see many tourists there. On the way to the temple you can buy tacky, chinese stuff and snacks. The temple is worth to see. Very colorful and the way through the Fort is nice
This temple is profound. One must experience it. Make sure to wear traditional dress if you want to do pooja offering.
This is a good trip to provide some variety from lying on the beach. There are great views from the bay from the top. I would recommend getting a tuk tuk up and walking back down.
It is something local and cultural. Not touristic. Be there when Pooja happens. You will see lot of local devotees and their culture.

This is situated inside the Trinco fort. An especially important place for Hindu people of Sri Lanka. even though it is Hindu religious place anyone can go and witness the ceremony. We have gone there at 6.30 A.M which is the best time in the morning. morning ceremony starts at 6.30 and you can witness typical Hindu music and traditional items there. Don't forget to go to the rock edge where you can see the sun rising from the horizon. it's a great view. Have a taste on sweets on the way. Deers are a common site in the area.

We visited the temple after a dolphin watching boat trip (highly recommended) - and although the temple is of historic significance in the local area, there isn't alot to it. We only really spent 20 minutes here - just to put it into perspective?

I've seen a few temples and sacred places, but I did not like this one at all. I don't understand all the positive reviews... Ok, the spot above the ocean is nice and the path to the temple is also very peaceful with those chunky trees and the deer around... But the temple itself was very dirty and not really nice. No interesting paintings or other things, very impersonal... Oh there were some monkeys... but that's it ;)
A pretty little temple with outstanding views over the bay , stalls are lining the road up to it with the usual temple tat . Very pleasant .

accessible to everyone. A kovil with a long history. Thers a viewpoint inside the premises. Beware of monkeys on the way could grab your food from hand. Can see lot of deers who are friendly and wont runnaway from you. Remove your slippers when entering. Shorts are not desirable.

There is parking available at this temple free of charge. The walk to the temple is quite short but a little on the hilly side. There are stalls selling offerings to take with you to the temple and also stalls selling drinks and ice-creams. Once you get closer to the temple you have to remove your shoes as usual and pay Rupees 20.00 to reclaim them again. The ground in the afternoon to the temple once you remove your shoes can be rather challenging as it becomes very hot. The temple itself is well worth a visit and the views from the top are truly magnificent. Sadly there are many spotted deer that have taken residency next to the temple, and have begun to beg for food from the devotees. Many people, including ourselves, stop to take photographs of the resident spotted deer. I only hope that people do not get them too familiar with begging for food due to feeding, that they completely forget how to forage for themselves.
Pretty, lively and lovely with a real sense of occasion, was even blessed. Hot in the day and you have to take your shoes off, hard for westerners in 40 degree heat. Great place - go!

I have never seen a temple that is built on edge of a beach cliff. You can easily find deers and peacock casually moving along with the peoples. You can also find few shops on the way to temple. One of the famous places to visit in tricomalee. we went on December 10th early morning..it was so beautiful,

This temple is located inside Fort Frederick, which still operates as a military fort.  The temple is located right at the end of the peninsular.  It is a fabulous location for a busy hindu temple.  I got the impression that the temple itself is quite modern, but that does not detract from its drama

The level of details in this Hindu temple was impressive. We unfortunately missed the pooja (prayer). You should plan to be there at the right time, so you get the full experience. 30-45 min drive from Trinco city.

A beautiful and historic temple overlooking China Bay. It is our first visit to the place and learned that in 17th century Portuguese invaders demolished it and robbed of all valuable, killed all priest in an attempt to convert hindus to christianity (or just blood thirsty and looting). It only rebuilt  in 1950s after discovery of relics by Arthur C Clark and town council of Trincomalee. A must see place in Trinco.

One of the most important Hindu temples on the East Coast of Sri Lanka; it's usually very busy and so it's worth observing the religious practice of the visitors. Taking photos inside is forbidden, except if you are so lucky as to witness a Hindu wedding there (as we were :) )

This is one of the beautiful Hindu Temple around the country. mainly with the location is very attractive, from this location you can see the city and Ocean.This Hindu Temple has a long History with God Shiva, and King Rawana.

This is a famous kovil/ temple among Sri Lankans - specially among the Tamil people. Good place for foreigners to experience the culture and religion of people in this area. Better to go in the morning - since the weather is usually hot. If you want to participate to the Pujawa - you have to first pay Rs. 100 and take a ticket and then go to the Sami with that for Pujawa. Tickets are issued inside the temple.
We had a wonderful experience to worship that kovil temple. It located Beautiful area surrounding the ocean.it's a best experience we had.
An amazingly detailed and painted temple. The figures of Hindu mythology are a treat to see. A functional and busy temple that's definitely worth a look.
Colourful and lively, great views from vantage points, locals offering fruit everywhere (felt bad declining the fifth banana).

A nice clean and peaceful temple surrounded by indian ocean. Prayers start at 6.30 am and then from 8.30am till 11.30am. Need to park a distance away and walk up the temple. There are shops along the way to buy the neccessary prayer items. You may see deers on the way up to the temple.
Many Sri Lankan used to visit this kovil in expecting babies. Anyhow the scenery you would enjoy is priceless and couldn't find such high-sight view of Trincomalee sea from any place here.

Following a gentle walk up to the temple passed a few stalls selling hats and souvenirs we saw the colourful statue with the temple behind. We were privilaged to be allowed to join a ceremony  and (we are female) local females showed us what to do. We bought a ticket at a kiosk to give to the priests to bless us. The temple is beautiful inside but no pictures allowed. Behind the temple were lots of little cradles hung on trees for fretility wishes. Beautiful views out to sea and across the bay. We ended with a cool orange juce in the cafe on the hill where we watched the sun set.

The Koneswaram temple is one of most holy Hindu shrines to the god Shiva in Sri Lanka and is well worth a visit. It is easily approached by car or the ubiquitous tuk tuk readily hired close to most local tourist hotels around Trincomalee town. The high rock on which the temple stands gives great views out to sea and coast. Be aware that the dropping off point is a hundred yards or so from the temple near a range of souvenir stalls. The last part of the approach requires bare feet (this can be a bit hard on the feet) as is usual when visiting shrines and shoes can be deposited in a rack for this purpose. The temple and surrounds are lavishly decorated with colourful statutes and a number of dioramas illustrating stories from the lives of the gods.

This is a must see place if one visits Trinco. It is very easy to reach and you can take your vehicle quite close to the temple. It tells you many epic stories about the hindu gods and also offers some spectacular views (Ex: Lovers Leap). The views get even better if the sun is out nice and bright. Don't forget to see the Portuguese cemetery on your way.

Before you get to the temple you are asked to take off your shoes. It is nice to walk through the temple grounds and take a few photos. Inside the temple, however, you are not allowed to take photos. If you have a few minutes to spare, stop by one of the cafes on the side on the road and enjoy a cold drink and a panoramic view of Trinco. Also, be aware that taxis and tuk-tuks are not allowed too close so you will have to walk a few minutes before getting there.

We family of 12 with chidren visited in the evening  .nice atmosphere, there are 3 wheelers who charge rs100 for tranporting from car park who cannot walk. It is surrounded by sea .this the temple where ravana worshipped lord shiva.

For us- Europeans - it was the first experience with hindu temple. Very colourful, you experience a different culture by many sences - aroma sticks, colours, barefoot. If you pay 100 rupees, you get blessing from the monk.very nice, I recommend it.

If you visit Trinco you should not skip this place. When the time we visit this temple there were very less crowd. What a nice and calm place in Trincomalee and also you can see a large number of deers in and around the temple. I highly recommend this place for all type of visitors.

Koneswaram Temple of Trincomalee (Tamil: திருக்கோணேச்சரம் கோயில்) or Thirukonamalai Konesar Temple – The Temple of the Thousand Pillars and Dakshina-Then Kailasam (Southern / Ancient Kailash) is a classical-medieval Hindu temple complex in Trincomalee, a Hindu religious pilgrimage centre in Eastern Province, Sri Lanka. The most sacred of the Pancha Ishwarams of Sri Lanka, it was built significantly during the ancient period on top of Konesar Malai, a promontory overlooking Trincomalee District, Gokarna bay and the Indian Ocean. The monument contains its main shrine to Shiva in the form Kona-Ishvara, shortened to Konesar.

What a colourful and nice temple this is in Trincomalee. After you entered Ford Frederick you have to walk a bit towards the temple; we did this late afternoon which was great with regard to the heat. Outside there is a large statue of the Godess Shiva which is impressive. Inside there are lots of colourful statues to see; we were lucky as a ceremony just started when we arrived. Be aware, at an Hindu temple women need to wear a sarong and you have to enter without shoes.
Very beautiful maintained tempel that's definatly worth a visit when you're in trincomalee. Keep in mind you need to cover your knees and shoulders
If you are a Meditation expert,  Nature lover, person like to see the wolrd in a lonely place, please make sure to visit this place,,, If you have Reiki  expert you ahve more to Feeel

I like temples so this was high on my list.  It sits on the hill at the top of the cliffs at the end of the peninsula with great views.  The temple itself is impressive with fascinating pictures and artefacts.  If you like temples, this is a great visit.

The temple was beautiful. Situated in the east of Sri lanka trincomalee and overlooking the Indian Ocean. The temple is filled with cultural significance. It is said that ravana used to pray here to shiva along with his mother and is also said to have brought the lingam from kailash. It has been destroyed once by tsunami, once by the tsunami and is the third construction standing now.
As one of the 5 Siva temples in Sri Lanka this is a must to see and experience. Great views out to sea from here as well.
This place Is worth visiting, lot of free running animals. And beautifull view on to the sea. The temple is very color full

Ravan wanted to cut off the temple from the mountain it was on to let his mother, who was ill, have darshan. As he was cutting it away he got news of her demise.and rushed back.there is a huge cleft between the rocks which is called Ravana's cut, There is a lovely viewing gallery for looking out at the sea. the temple itself is relatively new as it had been destroyed by the Dutch in 1614 and was later reconstructed but a real worth it visit.

I've already reviewed this temple as part of my review of Fort Frederick, which you have to pass through to reach the temple.  It's very colourful with lovely paintings and statues showing the destruction by the Portuguese of the original temple built on this site.  There is an enormous Hindu god statue next to the temple, and several small shrines among the rocks nearby.  Anyone is allowed to enter the temple as long as they remove shoes and headgear.  It is one of the most important temples in Sri Lanka, and receives a lot of visitors.

While I stood through the morning service I can't pretend to really understand what was going on but the Faithful were clearly enraptured by the spectacle. Later we went along the cliff-edge path with great views of the ocean. Those unused to walking barefooted should be aware that you have to leave your shoes a fair distance from the temple so socks may be a good idea in the heat of the day.
A very  religious place where people from all religions visit when in Trincomalee.and a very religious place and as a Very long history.it's Location is fantastic

An interesting place to visit of great religious importance to Hinduism, in a nice location on the top of the hill overlooking the Indian ocean. Bright colourful drawings and sculptures on the walls and statues with vivid colours very common in Hindu temples. There are deer and peacocks on the way to the temple and many vendors. The only negative comment is the trash everywhere and the bad smell.
Definitely worth a visit if you're in the area. Large statue of Shiva is impressive. Setting is quite extraordinary, perched on a promontory above the sea.

On the walk up to the temple there are a number of wild deer running around. Around the entrance are a number of market stalls selling food, drink and souvenirs. King coconut drinks are cheap if you haggle. The temple is very vibrant and colourful, and also busy. Women are given extra robes to cover of up if required. Shoes are looked after for 20 rupee. Temple has great views of the main bay. Would recommend the walk up there.

We walked up from Trinco and enjoyed walking through the army base and seeing all the deer. Small entry fee and remember to cover up. Temple was very colourful with lots of ancient relics. Is currently under construction so some bits were covered up. View of the sea is amazing - whilst there we saw loads of huge jellyfish in the sea! Worth a visit if you want some time away from the beach!

This a very important place in trincomalee.even in sri lanka.wonderful place snd its fantastic.you can view whale trincomalee city from this place And this place has very powerful mythology.its a valuble ancient place in sri lanka
This was a great holy place to visit I visited this Kovil with my husband and daughters so many travellers came to this holy land

This Ancient Temple located on a rocky outcrop overlooking the ocean is a must for all visitors to Sri lanka.  Sacred to Hindus , is also full of history and hindu culture.   A lot to see and absorb in the design and architecture of the temple.    Modest dress and no footwear

I recently visited the Koneswaram Temple.  It is a small temple, and nice for a quick visit. You have to take your shoes off a way before the temple and it is very uncomfortable walking on the gravel up to the temple. No idea why they don't put something down over the gravel. Hard for tourists to walk on this and also the ground gets very hot.

Review Title: ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ A Sacred Place That Touches the Heart – My 3rd Visit
Review Text: I visited Thirukoneswaram Kovil in Trincomalee last week, and once again it reminded me why this temple is so special. This was my third visit, and every time I come here, the experience feels new, peaceful, and deeply spiritual. The moment you step inside the kovil, you can feel the calmness. The sea breeze, the ancient architecture, and the powerful energy of the place make your mind completely relaxed. The view from the top is truly breathtaking — the blue ocean stretching far beyond your eyes. It feels like nature itself is giving you a blessing. The temple premises are well maintained and very clean. Watching people pray with devotion, hearing the bells, and standing in front of Lord Shiva’s sanctum gives a beautiful sense of peace. Every visit makes me feel more connected to my faith and culture. If you are visiting Trincomalee, Thirukoneswaram Kovil is a must-visit, not just for religious reasons but also for the history, beauty, and the peaceful atmosphere it offers. I know this won’t be my last visit — this temple always pulls me back with its divine charm.

Another  very colourful temple, but in a spectacular location, and so colourful and bright.  Worth the visit for the views and lovers leap. Few stalls on the way up that have some interesting local food.

Very colourful place high on a cliff top. You have to leave your shoes at a booth before you can proceed to the temple. Knees to be covered sarongs available at the door if required. Should have worn socks as the ground was so hot a bit uncomfortable to say the least. Plenty of stalls along the way.

It's a great temple with lots of action going on. Drums and trumpets playing in a very nice and colorful temple. Lots to see for people who are new to Hinduism. The view from Swami Rock is great aswell, especially during sunset. Would advise to go one way at least by Tuk Tuk if you stay in Trincomalee.

This temple is beautiful and it's free. You can see the locals pray and catch a great view of Trinco. Women should cover shoulders and legs. They do have covers available at the entry. We were pleasantly surprised by how much we enjoyed this.
Thirukoneswaram or the Holy Koneswaram Temple, is a Hindu temple in Trincomalee on the east coast of Sri Lanka.The temple lies on a high rock.It surrounded on three sides by the sea.

Loved this Hindu temple, so bright with its beautiful paintings and statues. Very movi g and spiritual place with an i teresti g yet sad story of the girl who lost her lover and jumped into the ocean.  Beautiful setting over looking the sea. A must visit
a little wark up to the temple ...quiet...u can see alot of deers on the road ...view from on top of the rock is nice  ..has a history ....
I´ve visited many temples of a wide variety of religions in many countries. I never saw an advertisment like the one they have in the entrance. It seems they are quite rigid!!

Visited temple on Saturday morning, so it was super busy, even more - there was wedding happening, with couple receiving blessing (if that's how it's called) - it was amazing to see and was our highlight of visit to Trincomalee, which in off season was very quiet. I also found people around temple very welcoming (I saw maybe about 5 more people besides us who were not local), lots of sales booths, but no one bothered us.
Unless you are interested in participating in the rituals go in the evening about 4 p.m.  Lots of visual and cultural interest outside, especially as no photography is allowed inside.

The Koneswaram Hindu Temple is definitely a 'must see' when in Trincomalee. One has to walk for a few minutes along the road leading to it (with no shoes), then a short climb up into the Temple itself. You pass numerous street vendors selling sweet foods, hats and souvenirs. The Temple itself is a masterpiece of architecture and Hindu decorations and art work. Apart from the glory of the Temple one can enjoy superb panoramic views from the grounds, overlooking the town and distant beaches.
A gorgeous and beautifully located temple full of friendly worshippers. Colourful and glorious. An easy walk. The sweet looking cow outside the temple is actually an attack cow... beware!
Best place in Sri Lanka 🇱🇰✌🏽visit this if your in trincomalee for many years this god has given blessings to all our country

THIRUKONESWARAM HINDU TEMPLE, TRINCOMALEE Koneswaram hindu temple located in trincomalee the eastern capital of srilanka. This place have a long history and a heritage of a hindu's.  Devotees pray here four times a day. [6 a.m/ 8 a.m / 11 a.m/ 4 p.m]. You have to wear long dresses because shorts dresse prohibited to enter the place.Couples hoping become parents come to this place because of the trust in their hearts.This is like a heaven in srilanka and highly recommend for nature lover and tavellers.

Nice visit for free! You can also visit fort Frederic and a Buddhist temple there everything is free Entry! The solfiers there are very nice and caring that No Tourist pays money for something free! Nice people.

Climb the Fort Frederick hill and the temple is at the top.One of the more interesting of the dozens of Hindu Temples that you will visit. It is one of the three principal places of worship dedicated to Shiva. There are no photos inside but great water views outside. In the afternoon they have a special ceromony with lots of drums and music.

Nice setting on a cliff  high above the sea. Mainly frequented by local Hindus who can purchase in one of the stalls along the road leading up to the temple. Some tourists also stop here on their way to a beach resort. On hot days the ground can burn your feet outside the temple so you might want bring socks...

this Temple with a connection to ancient history is worth a visit.   A place sacred to the Hindu people, so no footwear, no head gear, and no photos.   Can watch a pooja ceremony  conducted by the hindu priests
Grate Hindu Temple. Best time to visit early in the morning. Lot of visitors from all over the world visit this temple.

Was lovely and cool inside this air conditioned restaurant which was a bonus. Kids had pizzas which were fine but sadly my nasi gorang was burnt and every mouthful tasted of burnt rice which was very disappointing. I'm not one to complain but I won't be going back. Also were bothered by flies so waiter positioned a fan next to the table to try and blow them away from our food!

This is a really lovely Hindu Temple in a great setting, up on a hill, right by the ocean.  There are various caves and niches in the rocks that have been used to house some of the Hindu idols / artifacts.

One of the best Hindu Temples in Sri Lanka. Dravidian architecture, colourful paintings & statutes of gods make this temple colorful and glamours. A must visit attraction when in Trinco! Recommended for families with children!

This is a beautiful temple with a lot of old artifacts and history dating back to the time of King Ravana. The location is fabulous, with views of the Trincomalee town and the beaches from the temple.

Took a tuk-tuk to this temple, well worth a visit. There are market stalls trying to sell you stuff as you walk up to the temple.  The temple is is good condition and is set on a cliff with lovely views of the sea. We accidentally forgot our longer clothes and thankfully there was some we could borrow (20rupees) to use. The shoe man who minds your shoes cost 20rupees also-just to be aware. But it was lovely and afterwards we stopped at the first stall on the right as you’re going back down and got a lovely king coconut and pineapple juice (best I’ve had on the trip!) drank them overlooking the ocean and the town of Trincomalee as the sun was starting to set-heaven!
The place where temple is located is very beautiful, specially in evening. Historical background also nice. can see the bay and trincomalee city nicely.

Got a tuk tuk to the temple which is at the top of the hill. The temple itself is very beautiful. There was a ceremony going in when we visited but we were still welcome to enter- just couldn't take photos inside the actual temple - only outside. The view of the ocean, beaches and town is amazing. We then walked back down the hill - through the market along the road - and down through the Fort to the fort entrance. At the entrance to the temple you leave your footwear in a basket, you get given a ticket, and on return you collect your footwear and pay a 10 rupee fee. This temple is a must visit.

We went up to the temple but was not permitted to drive up all the way up the hill to the temple as there was a problem with the historic arch leading up to the temple. There was water leaking from beneath the arch and the authorities were worried that it might collapse. so we walked up the rest of the way which was a few hundred from where we had parked our coach. The temple and it architecture was beautiful and it s location on the hilltop overlooking the bay was beyond description.The view from the temple across the bay was fantastic. We even sighted a peacock in the vicinity of the temple in the bushes surrounding the temple hill side.We spent about twenty minutes in the temple and having prayed left and walked back. As you cant wear your shoes into the temple, there is a small stall on the left hand side as you near the temple where you can leave your shoes for a small token sum. All of you in the group can put your shoes/ sandals or slippers in one compartment. A number of the closet holding your shoes will be given to you to collect them on your return. the temple is worth a visit as it is of historical interest.

If you are into temples then worth a look because its built on the hill and the scenery is worth the trip ,you will have to go through the local market place to get their, as usual the markets are full of local produce all very snuggery so be aware you diabetics , and pick the stall that has a cover over the food because the place can be full of flies , do keep your hand bags secured or the monkeys will have a field day pulling things out that you do not want anyone to see. I am not into pagan worship mind you we do have a lot of pagans ruling our world at present.
This place is a Hindu temple for god Shiva. you can get a very nice view of surroundings and sea from here. they charge high for keeping your shoes.that is not acceptable.
It was the weekend when I visited and also a festival, people friendly. I was the only westerner on this occasion. I think more tourists visit at other times

Koneswaram temple is known as Thirukoneswaram & as Southern Kailasa. It's a must to visit Hindu temple. Main deity is God Shiva , Goddesses Parvathy & God Ganapati, along with other deities. They do puja rituals & if we ask they will give vibhooti/ bhasmam packed in covers.
Located in one of the most beautiful locations in Sri Lanka, it is a must visit for the travelers. A religiously important place as well
It was difficult to visit and hard to understand what they were doing in the rebuilding. Needed more interpretative signs in English
It was an amazing experience. Have a marvelous scenery at the top of the rock. I recommend everyone to visit this place.

This temple is placed inside an army fort just at the top of a hill. Must leave your footwear at the entrance paying 20RS fee. Nice views of the bay but as everything in this country full of plastics and rubbish around :(

This was the second time i visited the temple. You have to park it and climb a small mountain to go to the temple. its inside the fort. along the way there are many shops to buy local sweets, arts and crafts. please wear clothes that do not reveal bare arms and thighs if not you have to cover.
For me a person who has never bee to India, seeing hinduism practiced in front of me was an eye opening experience. The temple's architecture is fascinating!

Koneswaram Kovil is dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva. It is located at the head of Swami Rock on the Gokarna Bay, which a seasonal home to blue whales. The temple sits on a high ground above the bay of Trincomalee. This is also a prominent pilgrim center for Hindus and, is of a great religious value. It provides a jaw-dropping scenery on all sides.

Perched atop a hill and surrounded by the serene blue ocean, this beautiful and ancient Hindu temple is a true haven of tranquility. Nestled within the historic Fort Frederick, the temple offers a peaceful retreat for those seeking a moment of calm. At the start of the road leading to the temple, there is a parking area available. Visitors can wear slippers up to the temple’s entrance, where a small facility is provided to safely store them for a modest fee while you explore the temple. As you make your way toward the temple, the path is lined with street vendors offering a variety of souvenirs, giving you the chance to take home a piece of the experience
if your visit tricomali, this certainly is a comfortable place which is inevitable. you can feel clearly of the local flavor, but buy something local with local price too
A great Hindu temple on the cliffs. Very colourful and interesting to visit, seeing the locals coming to worship and making oferrings

I was in August of 2014 looking the restoration and I come back last month to check it. The works of restoration was amazing. If you will go, I recommend read first about the history to enjoy better this Temple. I will come back again sure! Namaste!

Such a "BEAUTIFUL" place with so much history! I seriously don't have words to describe. Plus the day we went there,was so much crowded because it was a long weekend vacation here in SriLanka,so many people were their to enjoy the eastern atmosphere!
This is a very famous place among all religion. They have magnificent statues. Can see the whole trinco city when you reach there.

This temple is amazing - the location on the cliffs with a beautiful ocean view; the vibrant colours and the calm, special feel about it. I’m not Hindu but I could sense why this place is sacred. No entry fee made a nice change. Really enjoyed spending some time there.

A most religious place in Hinduism.And my brother explained a lot about this kovil before our family visiting here..nice view of the sea covering this kovil.and atmosphere and religious beliefs peaceful nature.We thought to visit.it was really nice memory I ever had.hope to go there again next year
It is a place of worship for Hindus and everyone can go to watch it. This Kovil has a long history. This temple is located on top of a hill.

Surrounded by the dramatic Swami Rock and Gokarna Bay, the classical-medieval complex is Trinco’s biggest draw. The site is a major Hindu pilgrimage center, and one of the Pancha Ishwarams (five abodes of Shiva) built in Sri Lanka to honor one of the principle deities of Hinduism. This temple is situated in the village of Thambalagamuwa that was part of the medieval semi-independent feudal division called Thambalagamuwa Pattu. Prior to the arrival of Portuguese in 1622 and then Dutch colonial overloads in 1656, leaders of the Thambalagamuwa Pattu and others around it were independent rulers sometimes subject to Jaffna kingdom or Kandyan kingdom.
The location of the temple makes it all the more beautiful. We visited the temple when a local ritual was on and the sound of the drums was mesmerizing.
Gorgeous colourful temple situation on a cliff overlooking the ocean, very interesting place to see!

A place with a great history. You can get a beautiful sight of the Indian ocean. Try and visit in the evenings as you have to take off your shoes entering the premises and the beach sand on the location gets really hot

This is a very nice place and a must that you must do when visiting trinco. At night this place is soo calm and quiet that you can visit with your husband.Remember that the show protecting people will stop their job after 7pm
The colors and decoration of this Hindu Temple certainly catch the eye. I would recommend visiting during a service in order to obtain an idea of the ritual and solemnity of the place.

This location is accessed through the fort. You walk for about 1km from the car park to the temple gate. Along the way you see some interesting sites, there are plenty of vendors selling goods, but our highlight was stopping and enjoying freshly squeezed passionfruit juice while overlooking the sea below. 250lkr for a good size glass. Remove your shoes and cover up, then be prepared for a very colorful exhibit both outside and in.
Walk around a Hindu temple barefoot. Look at the ocean and get a taste of Tamil culture. Just a short walk from the bus station. Not to mention the very tame deer.
The best part of this location is you can get a breathtaking view of Trinco harbour. Apart from it, it's typical Hindu temple with lot of statues. You feel relaxed when going inside the temple.
A temple that must be visited. Stunning view of the Indian Ocean from the temple hill rock. A unique view and location, which no temple even in India offers
Fort prederick is most visiting place for tourists and it is a beautiful place in Trincomalee and many Deers around here can see.
One of the most important and holy Hindu temples in Sri Lanka, open all hours, gives you a good feel of the local Tamil culture.

The Temple of the Thousand Pillars and Dakshina-Then Kailasam (Southern / Ancient Kailash) is a classical-medieval Hindu temple complex in Trinco, a Hindu religious pilgrimage centre in Eastern Province, Sri Lanka. The most sacred of the Pancha Ishwarams of Sri Lanka, it was built significantly during the ancient period on top of Konesar Malai, a promontory overlooking Trincomalee District, Gokarna Bay and the Indian Ocean. The monument contains its main shrine to Shiva in the form Kona-Ishvara, shortened to Konesar. The complex was destroyed in colonial religious attacks between 1622 and 1624 and a fort was built at the site from its debris. A 1632-built temple located away from the city houses some of its original idols. Worldwide interest was renewed following the discovery of its underwater and land ruins, sculptures and Chola bronzes by archaeologists and Arthur C. Clarke. It has been preserved through restorations, most recently in the 1950s. Granted ownership of villages in its floruit to form the Trincomalee District, Trincomalee village is located on the cape isthmus within the compounds. Revenue from the temple provides services and food to residents. Koneswaram has many strong historical associations. The shrine is described in the Vayu Purana, the Konesar Kalvettu and Tevaram hymns by Sambandhar and Sundarar as a Paadal Petra Sthalam along with its west coast Ishwaram counterpart Ketheeswaram temple, Mannar, and was praised for its tradition by Arunagirinathar upon his visit. The Dakshina Kailasa Puranam and Manmiam works note it as Dakshina/Then Kailasam (Mount Kailash of the South) for its longitudinal position and pre-eminence, it lies directly east of Kudiramalai west coast Hindu port town, while it is the easternmost shrine of the five ancient Ishwarams of Shiva on the island. This religious temple is well-preserved for all devotees and we have a lot of respect and believe in Lord Shiva as Sri Lankans. As Sri Lankans, we pay to visit the said temple and pay our utmost humble respect and worship Lord Shiva whenever we visit Trico or pass by this lovely town at any given time. People from all over the world visit this temple. It was an amazing feeling to visit back the said temple grounds with my family during our visit to Trinco again. We will always retain the said temple since we are so blessed to have the said temple in such holly /religious grounds of Trinco the history left behind and around the old port of Trinco which is one of the most amazing natural harbours of the world the said temple is amazing to watch to any visitors around the world.
One of the most beautiful temples I have been to in my life time, the sculpture and paint is so detailed and it’s not just outside it more amazing inside

This is a beautiful, spiritual Hindu temple located on top of a large hill/ mountain in Trincomalee, fully accessible by road and by foot. The carvings, paintings and religious artefacts are amazing and very interesting, with English texts providing guidance as to meanings etc. The views are also stunning, with views over the bay. Definitely worth a visit if in Trincomalee.

After a stroll up through many stalls selling drinks and offerings for the temples, you leave your shoes at the minder and wander up to the top of the hill.  It is a lovely temple with great paintings and an interesting collection of "cots" hanging in the trees -offerings from those hoping to have children. Many boats come here so the fishermen can come and pray before going out to sea. The temple has laid in ruins, been restored and enlarged over the years, and it became one of if not the most important surviving classical Dravidian structures by the 17th C.
The views of the ocean are beautiful from this temple. generally very interesting.  Take the time to read some of the explanations on the walls.

This is situated on a rock next to the sea. The Sea around this area is known to be very deep. Better to visit either in the morning or in the evening as it is hard to keep walking in barefoot, due to the heat.

It is a Hindu temple but a small one . Found probably manny years ago and seems to be a temple for blessing to have more children. A seaside view from the temple that is on the cliff do have a great look of the Indian Ocean ! You prepare to pay and remove your shoes to walk there! Do prepare to wear a modest dress when visiting .
The temple is very interesting, overlooking the ocean. It affects the strong spirituality. The entrance road is full of stalls but what is striking are the garbage and fawns
Please definitely visit this place IF you wish to see the true beauty of Trincomalee. The breathtaking view and the holy place is just taking you away from this world.
This place is definitely worth visiting. There are many beautiful temples. Very colorful and historical. I highly recommend.

A beautiful temple located on the cliff with a amazing view of the ocean. The history of the temple either written in sinhala or tamil language. If someone could explain about the stories the visit would be more interesting.

It is one of the most important Hindu temples, indeed sacred complexes, in Sri Lanka. It is located in a scenic position overlooking the sea and to get there you need to enter the area of the fort. At the entrance there are many small shops especially food and many people: pilgrims, school children. You must leave your shoes outside the complex and then, hopping in the patches of shadow, get to the temple "of a thousand columns". The temple itself is beautiful but what makes it very special is the location. You must be dressed comfortably (shoulders and legs covered). Admission is free.

This would be one o the things to do ar Trincomale apart from enjoying the beach. The temple is up a hill and quite a walk from the bus station so preferably take a tuk-tuk uphill. The temple is nothing great but does give you great views of Trinco. There are any small shops lining the temple. On your way back walk downhill which is pretty pleasant and worth the effort.

Very low key Hindu temple. The paintings are excellent and tell the story really well. Very life like. One of the few places you see Ravana and the entire Shiva family together. The priests leave you alone and have no expectation of any money.
It was the first time we went to a Hindu temple. It was impressive, lots of people and lots of stalls where locals sell their products.
This is a beautiful temple , breathtaking and enormous. We had a lovely trip from Uppuvelie in a three wheeler.  On the way we stoped to see
Swung by when we were in the Trinco centre and very much enjoyed looking around the temple. It doesn’t take too long to visit but looks very cool!
This Indu temple is simply amazing with a wonderful view on the sea! Absolutely worth going! Dont miss it!

This Temple is a medieval temple dedicated to the lord Shiva. 17th century inscriptions state that the temple has been around even in 1580 BC. The temple is located on top of a rock (Konesar Malaio Swami Rock) overlooking the Indian Ocean. Also the beautiful stone sculptures depict many events in the temples history such as the destruction of the shrine by Dutch, creation of the Kinniya hot water springs by Legendary King Ravana. And another attraction is the “lovers leap” or “Ravana Cleft” a 350ft vertical cleft. It is a sight worth burning your feet on the hot rock face.

It's a busy temple and beautiful. I was amazed to see and learn about Hindu traditions and how people perform the ceremonies there. You can have a nice breathing view of the blue ocean and Trincomale beach. I had fruit juice there in a small shop.
Unique religious place with a picturous backdrop. Nice view from the top. Better to visit during puja times. Unless you have VIP, the vehicle has to be parked far away. ARUNA KONDASINGHE
Lovely location, good to see the sunset and sunrise from the top of the peak. It would be nice if the history was written in English as travelers would like to know about it

There is something exhilarating about standing on the top of a rock and taking in a magnificent view. From this temple, which is as close to God as anyone can get here in Trincomalee, the views over the Indian Ocean are sublime. There are small shrines built into the cliff and it is lovely to stand with Hindu devotees as they perform their rituals. The temple, the people, and the wonderful view make this place a worthy place to visit. On our way down the hill, after collecting our shoes, we sat in a coconut cafe, high above the cliff, sipping coconut water whilst immersing ourselves with this unforgettable cultural experience.
Nice to walk up the hill towards the temple and enjoy the view! Beautiful statues and impressive temple
Very auspicious place for Hindus. Our main object was to take 5 shivlinga darshan that are famous in Sri Lanka. This is one of them.
It should be a sunny day to go this place can see ancient sculpture all Hindu architecture. very colourful. Since its a temple should wear proper cloths.
Good temple. Learned new stories about Ravana. The temple is very neat and clean and offers excellent views of Indian Ocean.

Very religious place to see. It's a very nice place near to the town and its on a hill mountain. The entrance to this temple falls from. The fort gates and it is being surrounded with the army camp. Very safe and any vehicle can be taken very near to the temple. The lovers leap is also is here and many tourist visit here and you can see from the sea level as well as from top. The shiva linga is there and many worshippers come to worship. Stay in trinco and enjoy the surroundings.

The temple is small but colourful to madness and there are representations of unusual deities. It's atmosphere is relaxed. There is a service at 11 am. Also visit the little cave facing the sea. Great picture spot. The merchants on the way sell excellent honey based candy by the weight. Take your pick.
